en.value: I get up early on Tuesdays and go to the gym.
[k]Sometimes|Every day|Usually[/k] I go swimming in the morning.
We say something "usually" happens if it happens regularly.
She goes to the [k]gym[/k] three times a week.
I [h]never[/h] go to the gym in the morning.
I go swimming in the morning.
They don't do much during the week.
I have my book club on Tuesday night.
Time phrases we cannot use with "every": today, tomorrow, yesterday, tonight, this morning etc.
Type an adverb of frequency before the verb in the sentence.
I [k]often[/k] work from home on Fridays.
[k]Every[/k] [k]Sunday[/k], I eat dinner with my family.
You can use "every" with most other time phrases. Here are some examples. Try and think about something you do regularly and how you would say that in English.
Tuesday isn't good for me. I normally go to the [k]gym[/k] and get home [k]late[/k].
Select each word that indicates how often something happens.
How often do you go to the gym?
She [k]spends[/k] a lot of time with her family.
She always goes to the gym before work.
He never spends time with his family.
Match the beginning and end of each sentence.
Organise these words from least frequent to most frequent.
Select each word that indicates how often something happens.
Do you have a New Year's resolution?
Sometimes he cooks and sometimes I cook.
He [k]always[/k] has a coffee in the morning.
Select the two words that make up the phrasal verb in this sentence.
Select the words in the correct order.
Read and listen to the expression and keyphrase.
I usually go to my book club on Tuesdays.
I have my book club on Tuesday night.
I don't [k]do[/k] much on Tuesday because I get [k]up[/k] early on Wednesday.
Select the correct words to fill the gaps.
Here's a recap of the five adverbs of frequency we've learned so far. Read the sentences and think about whether they indicate a frequent or infrequent action.
We never get up early on the weekend.
How often do you go to the gym?
Phoebe and Ross are trying to fit their New Year's resolution into their routine.
Yes! I really want to join a [k]book club[/k].
There is a good one [k]on[/k] Wednesday. My friend goes.
She always goes to the gym before work.
In the present simple tense, we place "always", "never" and "often" before the verb, except for when the verb is "to be" - then they go after, like this:
She [h]often[/h] gets home late in the week.
Talking about what we normally do before and after work - Adverbs of frequency "always, often, sometimes" etc.

When we talk about our routines and our free time, we can say how often things happen by using a variety of words and phrases. For now, we're just going to learn six to help us say how often we do things in our free time.
Fill in the gap using the audio.
I always have a coffee in the morning.
Select all the places (X) where "sometimes" can go.
He gets home late on Wednesdays.
I never get up early at the weekend.
We [k]often[/k] [k]go[/k] for lunch at this restaurant.
There are lots of different ways of talking about what we do outside of work. For now, let's learn a few different hobbies and routines. Then, we'll learn to talk about how often we do them.
Fill in the gaps with the correct letters.
We never get up early at the weekend.
Complete the sentence by typing in the box
Match the beginning and end of each sentence.
He usually has his book club on Mondays.
Select the correct word(s) to fill the gap.
Listen to the dialogue and fill in the gaps.
He goes to a French class on Thursday.
They [k]s[/k][k]p[/k][k]e[/k][k]n[/k][k]d[/k] a lot of time together.
She spends a lot of time with her family.
Type an adverb of frequency at the beginning of the sentence.
What do you do after work?
Every Friday we have our French class.
I often go running with my brother.
Sometimes I get up early and go to the gym.
He usually gets up late at the weekend.
Ah, I can't on Wednesday. I have my Spanish [k]class[/k] and I get [k]up[/k] early on Thursday. I don't do much on Tuesday, though.
I always drink coffee in the morning.
You should practise your guitar every day.
He goes to a French [k]class[/k] on Thursday.
We usually go running on Saturdays.

Guess what! You've just learned a new type of verb! "To get up" is made up of the "base" verb "to get" and the preposition "up". We call this a phrasal verb, and English uses these a lot. We'll see more of these in other lessons.
He usually has his German lesson on Fridays.
What do you do after work?
There are only certain places in a sentence where we can put these words. By learning a few basic rules, your sentences will sound coherent and natural.
"Every..." can either go at the beginning or end of the sentence; "sometimes" and "usually" can go at the beginning, end, or before the verb, like in the examples below.
I have my book [k]club[/k] on Tuesday night.
Select all of the words that we can use with "every".
We use this word for actions that happen very infrequently.
She spends a lot of time with her family.
